title: Macron: Chance of Brexit deal to be evaluated by end of the week
text:
French President Emmanuel Macron | Pool photo by Koji Sasahara via EPA Macron: Chance of Brexit deal to be evaluated by end of the week French president said the ‘principles of the European Union’ must be maintained.

French President Emmanuel Macron told Boris Johnson Sunday that the prospects of reaching a Brexit deal should be evaluated by the end of the week.

Macron and the British prime minister “spoke this morning" over the phone and Johnson presented his latest proposals, according to an Elysée official.

The French president "indicated that the negotiation should continue quickly over the next few days with [EU Brexit negotiator] Michel Barnier’s team, in order to evaluate by the end of the week if a deal is possible, in accordance with the principles of the European Union," meaning the integrity of the single market and stability in Ireland, the official said.

The call came after Johnson wrote in two British newspapers that the United Kingdom will be “packing our bags and walking out” of the EU in 25 days.

"The only question is whether Brussels cheerily waves us off with a mutually agreeable deal, or whether we will be forced to head off on our own,” the British prime minister wrote.

In his call with Macron, Johnson stressed that this is the final opportunity to secure a deal, saying, “We have to push forward,” according to a Downing Street readout of the call. He also said that the EU must match the U.K.’s recent compromises in order to reach a deal, which he said he still believes is possible.

Johnson also promised Macron that his new proposals command support in the British parliament that the deal reached between Brussels and his predecessor, Theresa May, did not have.

“This is the chance to get a deal done: a deal that is backed by parliamentarians and a deal which involves compromise on all sides,” a senior No. 10 Downing Street official said. “The U.K. has made a big, important offer but it’s time for the Commission to show a willingness to compromise too. If not, the U.K. will leave with no deal. The surrender act and its authors are undermining negotiations, but if EU leaders are betting that it will prevent no deal, that would be a historic misunderstanding.”

Irish Prime Minister Leo Varadkar told reporters on Saturday that “time is tight” to find a compromise before the European Council summit on October 17 and 18.

Johnson also spoke to Portuguese Prime Minister António Costa over the weekend, and will continue talks with EU27 leaders Monday, Downing Street said.

This article has been updated.
description: French president said the ‘principles of the European Union’ must be maintained.
